questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common non-Hodgkin lymphoma in India?
questions.explanation:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma 
(NHL) in adults and children over the age of 15 years, worldwide, and in India. Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common NHL in children under the age of 15 years.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not caused by the Epstein-Barr virus?

options.b: Primary diffuse large B cell lymphoma of the CNS

questions.explanation:
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is the etiological factor for primary effusion lymphoma, not 
Epstein-Barr virus. Lymphoid malignancies associated with Epstein-Barr virus include: • Burkitt's lymphoma • Post-organ transplant lymphoma • Primary diffuse large B cell lymphoma of the CNS • Hodgkin's disease • Extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma, nasal type Primary effusion lymphoma is a variant of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma that presents with 
pleural effusions, usually without apparent tumor mass lesions. It is most common in the setting 1425 
Sold by @itachibot of immune deficiency disease, especially AIDS.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following types of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and its corresponding grade are 
correctly matched?

options.b: Diffuse large B cell lymphoma - Low grade

questions.explanation:
Burkitt lymphoma is a fast-growing, high-grade type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). NHL was earlier classified on the basis of its morphology and clinical behaviour. However, this 
classification is not currently used. Based on the clinical behavior, NHL is classified as: • Low grade - CLL/SLL (small lymphocytic lymphoma), follicular lymphoma • Intermediate grade - mantle cell and marginal cell lymphoma • High grade - diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), Burkitt's lymphoma The most aggressive NHL is DLBCL, whereas the most rapidly progressive tumor is Burkitt's 
lymphoma. Most pediatric NHLs are high-grade and aggressive.

questions.question:
Question 4: What is the most common extranodal site of involvement in patients with non-Hodgkin's 
lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
The gastrointestinal tract is the most common extranodal site in patients with non-Hodgkin's 
lymphoma (NHL). The stomach is most commonly involved, followed by the small intestine. The skin is the second-most common site. Mycosis fungoides is a mature T-cell (CD4+) NHL with 
skin involvement with eventual visceral and nodal spread. When malignant T-cells in the skin 
enter circulation, it is called Sezary syndrome. It presents as erythroderma (diffuse erythema and 
scaling). Histologically, there are Sézary-Lutzner cells (with cerebriform nuclei) and Pautrier 
microabscesses in epidermis. CNS is the most common extranodal site in patients with HIV infection. Primary CNS lymphoma 
(histologically, DLBCL) is one of the AIDS-defining malignancies.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is used to assess the prognosis in patients with non-Hodgkin's 
lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
The prognosis of patients with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma is best assessed using the international 
Prognostic Index (IPI). It consists of 5 clinical risk factors for poor prognosis: • Age >60 years • Elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) • Performance status  2 (ECOG) or 70 (Karnofsky) • Ann Arbor stage III or IV • >1 site of extranodal involvement Option A: Ann Arbor staging is used for anatomic staging to develop a treatment plan for 
Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Option B: Rai and Binet score is used for staging of CLL. 1426 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Hasford scoring is used to assess the prognosis of CML.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is incorrectly matched?
questions.explanation: Translocations seen in Burkitt's lymphoma are t (8;14), t (2;8) and t (8;22).

questions.question:
Question 8: A 59-year-old came to the OPD after noticing a swelling on her neck. On examination, 
painless lymphadenopathy was noted in the cervical, axillary and inguinal regions with no 1416 
Sold by @itachibot hepatosplenomegaly. CBC was normal. Lymph node biopsy showed effacement of nodal 
architecture with centrocytes and centroblasts. Which of the following immunophenotypic 
panels will confirm this diagnosis?

options.d: CD 19, CD79a, CD 20, CD10, CD 23, Bcl-2

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and the presence of centrocytes and centroblasts on biopsy are suggestive of 
follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping will be positive for CD19, CD79a, CD20, CD10, CD23, 
Bcl-2. Follicular lymphoma presents at a median age of 59 years with no sex predilection. The patients 
most commonly develop painless generalized lymphadenopathy. Systemic symptoms are absent. 
A lymph node biopsy is usually adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Characteristic 
features following lymph node biopsy include: • The normal nodal architecture is effaced by nodular expansions of tumour cells • Centrocytes - small lymphocytes with cleaved nuclei • Centroblasts - larger cells with vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli 1427 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following statements is false about diffuse large B-cell lymphoma?

options.a: It is a high-grade aggressive lymphoma
options.b: It is commonly associated with BCL-6 chromosomal rearrangements
options.c: It is associated with CNS lymphoma and intravascular lymphoma
options.d: It does not present with extranodal involvement

questions.explanation:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) commonly (>50%) presents with extranodal 
involvement at diagnosis, with the most common sites being the GI tract and bone marrow. DLBCL is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is a high-grade aggressive tumour. It is 
associated with BCL-6 chromosomal rearrangements and t(14;18). It is commonly associated with 
CNS lymphoma, pleural effusion lymphoma, and intravascular lymphoma. It is considered 
an AIDS-defining malignancy. AIDS-defining malignancies include: • Kaposi sarcoma • Primary central nervous system lymphoma (DLBCL) • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma • Invasive cervical cancer

questions.question:
Question 10: A physician is in Africa, working with the Doctors Without Borders group. He encounters a 
7-year-old boy with the following finding. His parents say that he had a jaw swelling for 2 
months that failed to resolve with antibiotics. A biopsy of the swelling reveals a starry sky 
appearance. Which of the following statements is true about this patient's condition? 1417 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is associated with n-myc dysregulation
options.c: Expectant management is the treatment of choice
options.d: It is associated with HIV infection

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of the endemic type of Burkitt's lymphoma. In this condition, 
the tumor cells are CD21+. Burkitt's lymphoma is an aggressive condition and is the most common NHL in children. This 
condition is endemic in African countries and is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) 
infection. It is associated with c-myc dysregulation, especially in cases in bone marrow 
involvement. Patients require aggressive management with high-dose chemotherapy.

questions.question:
Question 11: The lymph node biopsy of a patient with lymphoma is given below. It shows two different cell 
populations labeled as A and B. Which of the following statements is false?

options.a: Cells labelled A will test positive for CD14, CD40, CD11b & CD64
options.b: The fraction of cells with positive Ki67 staining is 100%
options.c: Cells labelled B will test positive for CD19, CD10, BCL-6 & CD43
options.d: Cells labelled B represent the stars in starry sky appearance

questions.explanation:
The given image shows the characteristic starry sky appearance of Burkitt's lymphoma. The 
reactive macrophages (labelled as A) represent the stars in starry sky appearance. On the other 
hand, the homogenous tumour cells (labelled as B) represent the sky. The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with a high growth fraction. These 
cells are positive for CD19, CD10, BCL-6 & CD43. Reactive macrophages are scattered throughout the tumour. Their pale cytoplasm in a background 
of blue-staining tumour cells gives the tumor a so-called starry sky appearance. Reactive 
leukocytes and macrophages are not stained by special stains. They are positive for CD14, CD40, 
CD11b & CD64. The growth fraction of these lymphomas is very high, with frequent mitotic figures. The fraction of 
Ki-67+ (MIB-1+) stained cells is nearly 100%. 1428 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: Patients with which of the following conditions are at risk of developing salivary gland 
MALToma?
questions.explanation:
Sjogren's syndrome is implicated in salivary gland MALToma. MALT lymphomas are commonly associated with an underlying autoimmune or inflammatory 
process such as: • Sjogren’s syndrome - salivary gland • Hashimoto’s thyroiditis - thyroid • Helicobacter pylori gastritis - gastric (most common) • Celiac disease - small intestine The most common translocation associated with MALToma is (11,18). It has a good prognosis.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not a T-cell lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
Hairy cell leukemia arises from a late, activated memory B cell exhibiting post-germinal center 
features. Mycosis fungoides and anaplastic large cell lymphoma (also called null cell lymphoma) are both 
T-cell lymphomas.

questions.question:
Question 14: The peripheral smear of a patient who presented with generalized lymphadenopathy and 
hepatosplenomegaly is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given peripheral smear shows tumor cells with multilobulated nuclei called cloverleaf or 
flower cells. This is characteristic of adult T-Cell leukemia/lymphoma. This condition occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It 
is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to one year following diagnosis. It is 
characterized by the following clinical features: • Skin lesions • Generalized lymphadenopathy • Hepatosplenomegaly • Peripheral blood lymphocytosis, • Hypercalcemia

questions.question:
Question 15: A 55-year-old man presented with fatigue and dragging sensation in the left upper abdomen. 
Physical examination revealed massive splenomegaly and no lymphadenopathy. CBC revealed 1419 
Sold by @itachibot pancytopenia. Bone marrow aspirate yielded a dry tap. Immunohistochemical staining of the 
tumor cells tested positive for CD19, CD22, CD11c, CD25, CD103 and CD123. What is the 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia (HCL). 1429 
Sold by @itachibot In this condition, most patients present with symptoms related to cytopenias or splenomegaly. On 
bone marrow aspiration, a dry tap is obtained due to HCL-induced marrow fibrosis and the 
interlocking cell borders of hairy cells (distinct from myelofibrosis). Tumor cells share certain characteristics of memory B cells. CD11c, CD25, CD103, CD123 is the 
characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic of this condition. Pan-B markers such as CD19, 
CD20, and CD22 may also be positive. Note: Splenic marginal zone lymphoma involves both white and red pulp of the spleen, whereas 
hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp. All non-Hodgkin's lymphomas involve white pulp of 
spleen except: • Hairy cell leukemia • Hepatosplenic lymphoma

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following best distinguishes hairy cell leukemia from other B cell malignancies?

options.a: Hairy cells on a Wright-stained peripheral blood smear
options.b: Annexin A1 on bone marrow specimens
options.d: Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies called ribosome-lamellar complexes

questions.explanation:
Annexin A1 on immunophenotyping of bone marrow specimens is the best method to differentiate 
hairy cell leukemia from other B-cell malignancies. It has 100% sensitivity and specificity. Hairy cells on Wright-stained peripheral blood smear are an important diagnostic finding. Typical 
hairy cells are mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with 
elongated (hairy) projections. Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies called ribosome-lamellar 
complexes can also be seen in 50% of cases. However, these can be seen in other B-cell disorders 
also. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool and is positive in 95% of 
cases of hairy cell leukemia. However, it is not pathognomonic. The following pattern of bone marrow involvement is near to pathognomonic for hairy cell 
leukemia (>99%): • Diffuse infiltration of tumor cells with honeycomb appearance. • Individual cells have a fried egg appearance such that the nucleus of each hairy cell is 
surrounded by a halo of cytoplasm, as shown below. 1430 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Patients with hairy-cell leukemia are at a higher risk of infection with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Hairy cell leukemia is associated with infections of Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare. This is 
possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia. Among them, infection with 
Mycobacterium kansasii is common.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 45-year-old man presented with progressive fatigue and weight loss for 3 months. CBC 
showed pancytopenia. On peripheral smear, the following cells were seen, which also showed 
positive staining with TRAP. What is the drug of choice for this patient? 1420 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with 
elongated (hairy) projections, which are TRAP-positive. This clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy 
cell leukemia. The drug of choice is cladribine. Hairy cell leukemia is responsive to chemotherapy with interferon , pentostatin, and cladribine. 
However, cladribine is the preferred drug of choice due to complete remission in the majority of 
patients, and higher rates of long-term disease-free survival. It is administered daily for 7 days by 
continuous intravenous infusion. Chemotherapy-refractory patients have responded to vemurafenib, a BRAF 
inhibitor. Splenectomy is often associated with prolonged remission.

questions.question: Question 19: What subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma is most commonly seen in India?
questions.explanation:
The most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma in India is the mixed cellularity classical 
Hodgkin's lymphoma. In contrast, nodular sclerosis is most commonly seen in western countries. The most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma in: • Developed/ western countries - nodular sclerosing 1431 
Sold by @itachibot • Children - mixed cellularity • Females - nodular sclerosis (but Hodgkin's lymphoma is more common in males overall) • HIV-associated - mixed cellularity • EBV-associated - lymphocyte-depleted

questions.question:
Question 21: What is the most commonly observed clinical presentation in patients with Hodgkin's 
lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
Supraclavicular or cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common clinical presentation of 
Hodgkin's lymphoma. The clinical features of Hodgkin's lymphoma are as follows: • Asymptomatic lymphadenopathy (non-tender with a rubbery consistency) is the most common 
presentation. • Most common - cervical or supraclavicular • Second-most common presentation - mediastinal mass • Hepatosplenomegaly in some cases • Pel-Ebstein fever: • Refers to recurrent febrile and afebrile intervals, each phase lasting for days to weeks • More common in older patients with mixed-cellularity Hodgkin’s lymphoma in an abdominal 
site • Alcohol-induced pain is a rare, unusual presentation

questions.question:
Question 22: A 29-year-old man with a 3-week history of fever is found to have multiple rubbery, enlarged 
lymph nodes. A biopsy reveals abnormal cells with bilobed nuclei that are positive for CD15 
and CD30. Which of the following is associated with this man's condition?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Hodgkin's lymphoma. The paraneoplastic syndrome 
associated with this condition is subacute cerebellar degeneration. Other paraneoplastic syndromes associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma include: • Minimal change disease (nephrotic syndrome) • Vanishing bile duct syndrome 1433 
Sold by @itachibot • Cholangitis • Alcohol-induced pain - pain typically occurs within a few minutes after the ingestion of even a 
small amount of alcohol and is localized to areas involved by HL Option A: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion is associated with small cell lung carcinoma 
of the lungs. Option B: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is associated with small cell lung carcinoma of the lungs. Option D: Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) is associated with 
adenocarcinoma of the pancreas and lungs.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following statements is true about Hodgkin's lymphoma?

options.a: Reed-Sternberg cell is specific for Hodgkin's disease
options.b: Classical Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with CD20 positive cells
options.c: Central nervous system is the most common site of extranodal disease
options.d: PET-CT is the most reliable technique for staging Hodgkin's lymphoma

questions.explanation:
PET-CT is the most reliable technique for staging Hodgkin's lymphoma. Reed-Sternberg cells on histology, point to a clinical diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma. However, 
they are not specific for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Reed-Sternberg cells can also be seen in the 
following conditions: • Infectious mononucleosis • Solid tissue cancers 1434 
Sold by @itachibot • Large cell non-Hodgkin's lymphomas (most common in immunoblastic type) Classical Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with positive test results for CD15 and CD30. Nodular 
lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with CD20 positive cells. The central nervous system (CNS) is an uncommon site of extranodal disease in Hodgkin's 
lymphoma. Lung, liver, bone, and bone marrow are the most common extranodal sites for the 
disease.

questions.question:
Question 26: A 49-year-old man is diagnosed with stage IIIB Hodgkin's lymphoma. Lab investigations 
reveal a hemoglobin of 10.8 g/dl, WBC count of 14,000/ µL, and an absolute lymphocyte 
count of 450/ µL. Which of the following are poor prognostic factors in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In this patient with advanced-stage Hodgkin's lymphoma, his age, gender, and absolute 
lymphocyte count all indicate poor prognosis. Unfavourable or poor prognostic factors for advanced-stage HL (stages III and IV) include: • Age > 45 years • Male gender • Haemoglobin (Hb) < 10.5 g/dL • Serum albumin <4 g/dL • White blood cell (WBC) count 15,000/ µL • Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) < 600/ µL Unfavourable or poor prognostic factors for early Hodgkin's lymphoma (stages I and II) include: • Large mediastinal lymphadenopathy • Involvement of 4 or more sites • Age >45 • ESR > 30 mm/hr • B symptoms - unexplained fever, night sweats or unexplained weight loss The selection of initial treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma is usually based on presenting stage 
and prognostic factors.

questions.question:
Question 27: A 48-year-old man with fever, night sweats, and weight loss is diagnosed with stage IIB 
Hodgkin's lymphoma. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The patient's age (> 45 years) and presence of B symptoms indicate an unfavourable prognosis. 
The treatment of choice in early-stage Hodgkin's lymphoma (stage I and II) with an unfavourable 
prognosis is ABVD regimen along with field radiation. ABVD is a combination of doxorubicin 
(adriamycin), bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine. The treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma is as follows: 1436 
Sold by @itachibot • Early Hodgkin's lymphoma (favourable and unfavourable) - ABVD regimen + limited field 
radiation • Advanced Hodgkin's lymphoma - extended course of chemotherapy with ABVD regimen. The side effects of this treatment include: • Doxorubicin - dilated cardiomyopathy • Bleomycin- interstitial lung disease • Vinblastine - SIADH, Peripheral neuropathy • Radiation - hypothyroidism, Lhermitte's syndrome, infertility Note: R-CHOP regimen is used in the treatment of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is composed 
of rituximab + cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine (oncovin) and prednisone.

questions.question:
Question 28: Which of the following lymphoid neoplasms is incorrectly matched with its corresponding 
etiology?
questions.explanation:
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is the etiological agent for lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma/ Waldenstrom's 
macroglobulinemia. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is associated with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) 
and Burkitt's lymphoma. Other acquired lymphoid neoplasms include: • Gastric MALToma/extranodal marginal cell lymphoma - induced by Helicobacter pylori 
infection • Intestinal T-cell lymphomas/enteropathy-associated T cell lymphoma - induced by 
gluten-sensitive enteropathy • Anaplastic large cell lymphoma in scar tissue - can occur following breast implants 1437 
Sold by @itachibot Coagulation Disorders
